stem: The nurse is preparing to administer a large-volume cleansing enema. Place the procedural steps in the correct order.

options.text: Position the client in the Left Sims position.
Lubricate the tip of the enema tube.
Open the clamp and raise the bag to the appropriate height (12-18 inches).
Insert the tube 3-4 inches into the rectum towards the umbilicus.
Instruct the client to retain the fluid for as long as possible.

rationale.correct: Correct enema administration prevents injury. (1) Left Sims follows the natural curve of the colon. (2) Lubrication prevents mucosal trauma. (3) Proper insertion depth/angle ensures passage into the rectum. (4) Height controls the rate of flow (Gravity). (5) Retaining ensures effectiveness of the cleanse.
rationale.incorrect: Inserting the tube more than 4 inches increases the risk of rectal perforation.
clinicalPearls: If the client reports abdominal cramping during administration, lower the bag or stop the flow temporarily for 30 seconds.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that if a patient cramps, you don't 'stop and remove'—you 'slow it down' by lowering the bag.

reviewUnits.heading: Bowel Elimination: Enema Procedures
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for potential vagal response (bradycardia/dizziness). Large volume enemas should be warm (105-110°F).
